text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for another
album review classics week continues
celebrating 50k 50k wu-tang clan enter
the wu-tang 36 chambers wu-tang is a
still active New York hip-hop outfit
that was formed in the early 90s this is
their debut LP dropped in 1993 and it's
been followed up with numerous studio
albums since but whoo tang is one of
those groups whose debut LP kind of
overshadows the rest of their albums
people usually don't give the rest of
their material the time of day even
though albums like their sophomore LP
wu-tang forever are pretty good but
that's not a huge issue since every
single one of the group's nine members
has released solo material and a lot of
that is as essential as 36 chambers like
Ghostface Killah solo stuff which is my
favorite out of all of the wu-tang
clan's solo release material fish-scale
ironman supreme clientele also Raekwon
with only built 4 Cuban Linx parts 1 & 2
ol Dirty Bastard with the return of the
36 chambers the dirty version and of
course we can't forget the jizzes Liquid
Swords those are some of my favorites
but no matter how much I like those
albums this release is the Alpha this is
where it all goes back to this is where
it starts and you must start now whoo
tang and this album were an essential
part to the evolving face of hip-hop in
the 90s this album is a move past the
golden age hip-hop sounds that came out
in the 80s the jazz rap and socially
conscious rap sounds that were being
dropped by groups like De La Soul and A
Tribe Called Quest in the in the very
early 90s and late 80s and the West
Coast sounds of gangsta rap that were
being dropped at the time too by guys
like Ice Cube
and waa and dr. dre keep in mind this is
just a really quick abridged version of
this evolution there are a lot more
artist sounds and albums at work here
because when people talk about this era
of hip-hop especially the west coast
side of things groups like freestyle
fellowship for example are often
forgotten so in the early in mid 90s the
New York hip-hop scene was reinventing
itself as something much grittier
tougher more aggressive and ready to
battle of course there are a lot of
individual New York emcees that played a
role in that like nas and notorious
b.i.g
but wu-tang definitely stuck out and was
unique in their amount of members not to
say that none of these guys would have
made it if they've stayed solo their
entire career but wu-tang power clearly
comes from strength in numbers because
with nine different people and seeing on
these really hard-hitting stripped down
beats this album sort of gives the
atmosphere the feel of a never-ending
cypher a rap battle there are a couple
songs here where one MC will take the
spotlight Method Man
where Method Man is all over that song
and of course claim in the front where
GZA is pretty much featured on that
track but on the majority of the tracks
here is just one MC after another taking
turns on these beats and because of that
it sounds like they're way more hyped
than they would be otherwise it's like a
competition it makes this record come
off with just a lot of energy and energy
that is really infectious and with
tracks that have gang courses like ain't
nothing to [ __ ] with and these really
hard hard grooves and rize's beats this
album has just a ton of momentum which
makes it really hard for me to just not
go nuts when listening to this thing and
because most of this album sounds like a
rap battle there's a very specific kind
of lyricism going on amidst these tracks
hilarious insults cartoony violence a
barrage of brags and non sequiturs and
cultural references there's about as
much ferocity and testosterone on this
as like a hardcore punk record so
there's no question that enter the
wu-tang is meant to be raw rugged dirty
and stoned but it's music you know it's
entertainment there's no reason to take
a lot of the violence and bragging on
this LP that seriously because it's so
outlandish and ridiculous the real goal
here is just to kind of be extreme and
out there which i think is definitely
highlighted on a sketch that comes
before the song Method Man where they're
kind of going back and forth talking
about torture and another clear goal
here is just to be clever funny witty if
you can get into the lyricism on this
thing you're going to hear a lot of
great wordplay and a lot of fantastic
quotables and to add another level of
greatness to this record I love that
every single emcee on this thing comes
into these tracks with a different sound
and a different style I hate it when I'm
listening to a rap track and it's got
two three four MCS on it and they all
sound the same
none of them have any flavor you can't
really pull anybody out is being any
kind of specific or bold thing not the
case here everyone on this album has
their own angle Ghostface Killah is the
most hyped MC out of all of them he
mostly works in the upper register of
his voice throws out a lot of battle
raps the GZA is extremely cunning and
clever in the rhymes he chooses Raekwon
has this nice rasp to his voice and he
pulls out a lot of vivid street life
imagery Method Man has this really kind
of partytime attitude he's really
chilled out laid-back
looking for a good time at every
possible direction and ol Dirty Bastard
who I think isn't the most lyrical here
but he's the most fun to listen to he
combines rapping with this really weird
kind of off kazoo like it's he's nuts or
he was rather he's got this really low
voice he slurs all of his words he's
like a rabid dog now let's talk about
the beats
a little bit I guess the beats on this
thing definitely helped bring wu-tang
together into this aesthetic of course
there was kind of a battle rap cypher
thing going on amongst these tracks but
there was also a certain sound to the
music behind the rapping of course the
name of the group is a tribute to old
kung fu movies and that definitely gets
brought home in a lot of the samples and
clips of dialogue from these films too
in the lyrics there's a lot of talk of
swordplay and martial arts and it really
kind of brings this album a huge sense
of of camaraderie like you're coming up
against a gang of lyrical ninjas in a
hip-hop dojo but overall the beats here
I think it's just kind of a case of of
less is more because it's not like
there's a whole lot to them and not to
say that they're not intricate not to
say that the sounds on these beats
aren't interesting I'm just saying it's
definitely not like a lot of modern
hip-hop which is just saturated with a
ton of different sounds poppin melodic
catchy hooks R&B singers on this thing
like a lot of hip-hop at the time there
are ton of piano samples but RZA didn't
just pick some kind of sweet or soulful
piano break or something like that it
seemed almost as if he was choosing the
most sour weird most unused melodies
notes and chords that he could get his
hands on because claimed in the front
7th chamber and Method Man all have
really weird piano phrases laid into the
beat and there are even moments like
cream where all the samples come
together to create something that's
really kind of chilled out atmospheric
and eerie the drums on here have a
really punchy analogue sound that's
really kind of typical for hip-hop at
that time really kind of classic style
and there are some songs on here that
clearly sample music from the very
kung-fu movies that inspire the group's
aesthetic - there's just one unique
sound after another in every one of
these beats and it just adds to the
aggressive and unsettling atmosphere of
this album they're very textured
instrumentals that just leave a lot of
room
just make space for the lyrics for the
emceeing and that's perfect to me like I
said these beats are just saturated with
a ton of sounds like today's hip-hop and
not to dis where hip-hop has gone I mean
I don't think today's hip-hop is
terrible I just think it's interesting
when you consider how much hip-hop has
changed in the almost 20 years since
this album has been released so yeah on
this LP there are a lot of brags battle
raps and tough personalities and beats
but it's not like that's the entirety of
this album there are some spots on here
that are worth kind of thinking about
the deeper meaning of like the song
cream which stands for cash rules
everything around me and even though it
sounds like a really kind of greedy and
stereotypical hip-hop statement that
song isn't really a celebration of that
it's just kind of a really gritty
picture of what it's like to grow up
poor and you're in a position where
making very fast illegal money seems
like the only way out of that and the
song tears which comes around the end of
this LP is about friends and family
members dying after making some bad
decisions like deciding to have
unprotected sex with a lot of different
people or refusing to hand money over to
somebody who's trying to mug you at
gunpoint 36 Chambers is definitely an
aggressive album but it's not an
aggression that should make you feel
threatened it's an aggression that you
get you pumped this thing is just a
messy grimy and unbreakable 90s hip-hop
album and there's not much more to it
than that this thing is a classic it's
an important part of hip hop's history
but if you're not a hip hop fan I'm not
going to promise to you that this thing
is going to change your worldview if you
haven't heard this album after all 36
chambers is the archetype for a lot of
the lyricism we hear in hip hop today if
you haven't heard this thing before and
you're just not all that school than
90's hip hop in general try this thing
out and at least get a sense for where a
lot of modern hip hop's ideas come from
just to kind of hear them at their best
for that time wu-tang 36
chambers counter chesa no one's who you
know is matching up the couch asta when
i spit this floor it's more electrical
than Tesla send your support please free
Cal so I could do some shows and tour
your locale you could quote me here my
rhymes are brand and clever I'm saying
it now but you'll be saying it forever
you
